Went with my friends Eva and Christian there and it was awesome!! Tried many different things there and everything was great. Was very impressed! Hope to come back soon!!!

Service and food are both amazing. This place is definitely a hidden gem.

I get regular cravings for their beef and lamb confit, and will drive 30 minutes just to pick up a bowl of it.

Seriously. This place is awesome. Go forth and nom nom.

I came to Vegas for a weeks vacation of R&R. No major plans except to enjoy time with friends and to eat good food. Well!..... we certainly found it here at Forte!  We weren't sure of exactly what tapas were. But when looking at the menu and reading the reviews, we knew this was a place to try. We were not disappointed! It was all delicious. My favorites were the stroganoff " deliciousness" and the Chorizo in Spanish Wine. My only regret is that we didn't allow near enough time for dinner. We had to be at another engagement and had only allowed ourselves 1 1/2hrs. This restaurant is designed to have many small meals, shared with friends and good company and to savor each dish, before the next one arrives. Our waitress was Amazing! My regrets that I don't remember her name. We are going to try and get there again before we leave! That's how good it is. You must try it!

Tapas are always our go to place for ladies night! Plus one baby of course. I came here because one of our ladies in the group recommended trying this place. Our server was tentative and the place has interesting dcor. We got a bunch of dishes together and shared it amongst each other. So many choices... Want... Everything...

Drinks: angry ginger lemonade, all the girls ordered their share of alcohol but I still enjoyed my drink the most so I got two! It has the taste of mule but it was YUMMY! You must like ginger. I believe Gypsy Milk was a close second.

Dates: I love dates and this was alright. it wasn't my favorite dish but would I order again? YES! Gets the cravings away. 

Forte Fries: such a simple yet delicious item. We got the one without the feta cheese. That dill on top was a nice herbal seasoning and it balances out the heaviness of fries. GOOD. GET IT.

Octopus in Olive Oil: lots of olive oil in it. Wasn't a fan of the octopus dish but the rice with it was good. 

Shrimp: We got the shrimp but I didn't eat any of it. I was too lazy to ask or reach for it. Silly reason right? It is pictured.

Bulgarian Mix: All the sausages and meats had excellent flavor. However, they were too salty for me. I wasn't a fan of this. 

Margarita Flat Bread: BOMB. I love margarita pizza and I always want to try it if I see it on the menu. The crust was nice n crispy. nice freshness from that basil and tomato with that crispy crusty goodness!

Feta Cheese roll: This is not pictured. But I think this bread was amazing!!! I couldn't stop eating it even after being full. They have a side of sour cream with it. I feel like the bread's texture was similar to the margarita flat bread. love, love, love!

Checked this place out after seeing it on DDD on Food TV. It's legit. Excellent food. Friendly homey atmosphere with cool art and lively music. The Thracian Clay pot was awesome!  The sausages were as good as they looked on TV.

I drive from Los Angeles just to eat here.

Food is incredible!! I lived in Bulgaria and know how the food should taste, and this is the real deal!  The nostalgia really sells it for me so perhaps my review is biased, but take it from my wife and the friends whom I've brought because they will also agree that the food is fantastic.

Service is good as are the prices. 
Atmosphere is very inviting and lively.
I'll be driving the 280 miles to see them again soon.

Thus far, I have had a great experience here, and then just an "ok" one.

The fist time I came here, it was perfect! My group of friends and I were seated in the back at a large table, food and drinks flowed. I ordered the Bangers and Mash dish. To put it simply, it was amazing. I really loved the flavor of the sausage, and the mashed potatoes were creamy and rich. I also got to try some of Vanessa N.'s Watermellon and Feta salad, which was also great. The drink of choice was the Moscow Mule, served in the classic copper mug. Also, I tried the Gypsy Milk. These too, super tasty and well balanced drinks. I really couldn't say anything negative after that initial experience.

Now... The second time was a bit different. I had recently seen Forte featured on TV, and wanted to try one of the dishes I had seen. This turned out to be the Thracian Clay Pot. I was so stoked to taste it, especially after not one, but two of my friends told me it would be delicious. 
Honestly, it was just meh. I didn't think it tasted bad, but it's not something I would ever order again. Nothing about the dish really popped. It was... Dare I say?.... Kinda boring. 

I will say that the drinks didn't disappoint. The mules again were great. And with that $5 happy hour price tag, they were even better. But I'm sorry, I gotta bring it up. There was some lady sitting at the bar while holding her dog in her lap. Really weird, and pretty unsanitary. And that dog really did not look like a service dog. As we left the restaurant, she and the dog were outside in the dark patio area and it started loudly barking at us. Umm, what? Luckily, I'm not scared of dogs (it was a small one), but what if I had been? Pretty much a turn off.

But David V. is spot on about the atmosphere. Very fun, lively and inviting. Still worth a visit.

Situated in a random strip mall, this place has a great ambience and good selection of Eastern European foods. Everything comes out tapas style, and we always order pelmeni which is our absolute favorite (I am Russian and know good pelmeni ). Drink menu is good too with great selection of infused vodkas and mixed drinks. The only downside is cold European service but it's kind of part of experience. The food is more tender than service...

I had always wanted to try this restaurant and finally stopped in to see what the hype was all about. Of course I was not disappointed. I had a great experience with fantastic food and friendly service. Blanca was very friendly and I appreciated the small things that are added to every dish to let you know how much the chef cares about your culinary experience. Try this place out. Did I mention the beer list? I also appreciated the overall value as well. Their servings are to a locals' standards.

I love this place! The inside decor is so fun. And we decided to be adventurous and explore the Bulgarian food. We were intrigued and delighted with the various dishes we ordered.
The owner also has an Eastern European charcuterie and the meats and sausages were obviously high quality and worth exploring.
re: complaints of smoking, yes, there was a table of women chain smoking. They were far enough away to not bother us and my BF is very smoke sensitive. Not sure why they are allowing smoking when it's now illegal in restaurants.

You can tell the owners put their hearts into this restaurant.

This place is in need of "Restaurant Impossible" makeover.  The place is painted black, with bizarre paintings on the wall, and some strange object that looks like a dinosaur dropping on a table. There was an odd lamp, with a shade that looked like underwear on it. 

I took off one star for the pounding weird loud music that played the entire time we were there. The owner needs to make this place a nice place to dine, or a dive bar. It is more on the edge of dive bar.

That being said, the food...seems to be hit or miss, depending on what you order. The meal started well, with the Mediterranean salad, fresh cucumbers,  tomatoes,  onion, with a delightful sauce. Ample portion for three to have a dinner salad. Another win was the fresh warm bread. The Sangria was weak, pass on that, tasted like Kool-Aid. The Borscht was served warm, with sour cream,  win on that.  The dumplings with meat, I did not care for them,  they tasted of liver to me. The worst dish was the flat bread with basil and tomatoes.  Greasy, not cooked through,  skip this. We also ordered sauted mushrooms,  served cold, meh...dessert was a honey "crepe", more like a pancake.  But it was served with powered sugar and walnuts. The latte I ordered came with whipped cream,  win. 

So, the food was okay...The service was also inconsistent.  We left, and went to Fat burger to use the restroom,  mainly due to the fact we could not stand the music and creepy decor any longer.  

I would not go here again.  And I am surprised at the rave reviews...and the patio, outside the Smith's, with view of parking lot,  joke.

Yes, I saw this on DDD.  Yes, I'm slightly embarrassed about that.  However, I'm more ashamed of the fact that this place is walking distance from my house, and it took my tragic Food Network addiction to draw my attention to it!

First things first...this place is pretty small.  There aren't a lot of tables, and the bar takes up much of the main entrance.  There is outdoor seating, but given that this is summertime in Vegas, and the restaurant faces westward, it's way too hot to sit out in the evening.  

Second thing - if you, like me, are vertically challenged, I highly recommend getting a seat in the restaurant area.  My group had a table in the bar area at first, and the chair was so high I actually had trouble getting on and off.  Comfy once I was up there though!

Service wise...this place was fine.  Our waitress was nice enough, but it didn't seem like she got our group's sense of humor.  She was efficient, but not overly friendly.  It was pretty busy, but we got everything we ordered in a reasonable turnaround time, so I had no issues with service.

The drinks were awesome.  I had the gypsytini to start the night, and although it's a "house secret" blend that my waitress couldn't describe, what I ended up with was a vodka martini that was lightly tart and fruity.  Very refreshing and tasty.  Another friend had the Ginger Lemonade cocktail, and the addition of fresh herbs like rosemary gave it a wonderful flavor.

We ordered a pretty decent array of food for our group.  It's hard to mess up almond-stuffed bacon-wrapped dates, so those were a fab way to start the night.  I ordered the varenikis, and I was a big fan of the fried onion topping.  The dumplings themselves were slightly cold, but it seemed like that had more to do with the sour cream juice (sorry for the lack of a more appetizing descriptor) cooling them down on the plate.  My buddy who hates onions actually loved the onions on this dish.

I grew up with a mom and grandmother who made goulash on a regular basis, and Forte's version was almost on par with my preferred version.  The chorizo we ordered was pleasantly smoky, but not as spicy as I would have liked.

One of my less adventurous friends actually ordered the adjarski khachapurri, which is finished table side by the server, who breaks the egg yolk and stirs it around to made a sort of custard spread for the bread boat.  Although he wasn't sure about it at first bite, by the time we looked up we had eaten the whole thing!  It was addictive and delicious, so definitely try it out.

All told we had six people, five of us with at least a couple drinks, and we ended up with a total bill of about $100 including food.  Not a bad price, and we'll definitely hit up this hole-in-the-wall next time we want something a little off the beaten path.
Must try the gin Rosemary lemonade! The shrimp with garlic butter makes for a great snack or starter to share -- but be sure to soak up the rest of the sauce with their wonderful, airy bread!

My husband and I went to Forte because my parents saw it on Diners, Drive-ins and Dives and my dad literally pestered me for MONTHS about eating there.

We ordered sangria, some beef dumpling thingy (pelmeni), the bread with cheese and egg in the middle, the thracian clay pot and stuffed dates. The pelmeni and cheesy-bread thing were kind of bland. The clay pot was flavorful, with yummy sausage, and I think I would get it again. The stuffed dates were the only food we ordered from the Spanish tapas side of the menu and they were good but almost overpoweringly sweet (Firefly's are better!).

Service was ok; sometimes it was hard to flag someone down when we needed something. My husband greatly enjoyed the propaganda posters in the bathroom.

What a breath of fresh air for the not so fresh in Viva. It's been a challenge finding fun and different places that are not steakhouses or dive bars. And as a bonus is in my neighborhood. Love the ambience and decor, and it's quite the surprise given it's sandwiched in a strip mall as others have mentioned. Moscow Mule is a must! Service was tops. Had the Spanish stew which was on special and INCREDIBLE. Had almond stuffed dates were good. The meat dumplings were okay but a bit bland. the prices are ridiculously good.

Go!

No, I haven't eaten here, but after watching DDD episode I have a serious crush on the chef... ummmm... the daughter, that is!  Can't wait to stop in next time I'm in LV. Lots of flavors going on there, to be sure.  (Now to look for a late night Bulgarian place in Chicago. Good luck.)

So, I've been here 4 or 5 times so far and YAY! I'm a fan!
Great happy hour. The drinks are great....love it. They have a moscow mule that is so damn delicious! They have a bunch of other drinks that are tasty too, but I always get the mule; it works!
The food is delicious. My fav......the bangers and mash. HO LEE COW. It's so good. I am very particular with sausage. I want to describe how I am, but it will sound so sexual (insert penis jokes) so all I will say is, there's is very good. 
The watermelon feta salad is absolutely delicious. I get it every time. The clay pot was so outstanding, Coudn't believe how good it was. Highly recommend. 
Natalia is a bartender/waitress and she is just amazing. So friendly, so helpful! 
It's a great place to chill with good friends, eat some delicious food and have some great drinks.

This place is fairly exotic, since few restaurants mix Spanish with Eastern European food.  I had never even heard of half the items on the menu.  The gazpacho was filled with various vegetables and I enjoyed it.  The Thracian Clay Pot was served HOT (temperature) and reminded me of a similar dish I had in Turkey.  I recommend this place if you want to try some food you've never had before.

Hubby and I went last night and absolutely loved everything! Service was impeccable. Staff took pity on first timers and guided us through the menu. If you are looking for a unique food experience this is the place. Food was amazing and not your standard fare. I would write exactly what we ate but can't spell it or pronounce it. lol Can't wait to go back. All the staff were super friendly. Excellent craft cocktails which I sooo appreciate.

We came here because of triple D and Everything was fabulous. We ordered a ton of things to share. Czar Burger, Bulgarian mixed grill, lentil and Spanish bean soup, Ibiza salad and the adjarski khachapurri which is to die for. (It is a must order item) To top it off we had a biscuit rum cake. We loved everything. It has a great blend of lots of different favorites from many European countries. I. Don't drink but they also have an amazing skeleton of liquors. I highly recommend this place!

I've visited here on two separate occasions and loved the food we had! The waitress suggested the Easter lamb which was incredible and came with a small salad and mashed potatoes. The lamb was really tender and tasted wonderful. Our waitress was friendly and knowledgeable of the menu. She suggested a few drinks to my party that were great! I highly recommend this restaurant and feel the atmosphere is unique and cozy!

This restaurant is a true hidden gem. You simply must check it out. The food is eclectic and so is the ambience. It does not feel like Las Vegas at all, actually. There is a lot of uniqueness, but none of it is kitschy. It is authentic European food, tastefully presented, with a nod to the old world, but firmly rooted in the new. It is colorful and tasty.

My wife and I went last night and Nina (the owner and star on DDD) took good care of us.  We tried all 3 dishes which were featured on the show (Adjarski, Tracian Clay Pot, and Mixed Grille) as well as the almond stuffed dates and the Garlic Fries.  The only thing we didn't have room for was the biscuit cake for dessert. Food was great and lets get to the good stuff, the cocktails.  

Must try the Angry Ginger lemonade with ginger infused vodka.  Also, my wife had the Sangria and she said it was the best she's ever had.  Finally, we tried a taste of Gypsy Juice.  Nina won't tell you whats in it but it is tasty.  All the drinks are very interesting and they even have a Russian beer.

Finally, atmosphere. Dark reds and Eastern European with a lot of interesting stuff to look at.

Overall, it was a small bistro thats easy to miss, but well worth the visit. Be sure to visit a fellow UNLV Rebel...

After reading about this fun new tapas place I convinced my finicky French fianc to try it out, it took a lot of persuasion, but finding a new place that is open until 3 would be perfect for me and my friends because we work so late. Well this isn't the place to go because at 12:30 on a Saturday the week Forte was reviewed and recommended in seven magazine, they were closed. No sign, no notice just a waitress behind locked doors trying her best to ignore us. So we went to a chain restaurant, one that we knew would honor their hours. Boo on you Forte boo on you.

I stopped by this place for lunch since the reviews were outstanding.  I'm not sure if they were having an off day or if this place was just not for me. 

First of all the atmosphere is unique.  It looks like someone bought a whole bunch of furniture from a garage sale and threw it in the space.  The chairs with the tables really don't work if you are trying to sit down and have a meal. 

There was only one server working the lunch crowd so service was super slow.  When she finally got around to us, she dropped off a bottle of vodka, what I thought,  to the table.  It was actually an old vodka bottle that they reuse to fill with water.  A little alarming to me as I'm not sure what health code allows but this was odd.   The server also dropped off a stale basket of bread in which they toast to hide the fact the bread was old.  Even my husband who is from Europe didn't even it.  

I ordered a mediterranean salad and the chicken shish kabob.  My husband had the borsht and the lescovacka pljeskavica.  Apparently, the borsht was not very good but the lescovacka was edible.  The flavors were to be somewhat desired in my opinion.  I barely touched my food and the server never even asked if everything was okay when she took it away. 

Based upon my experience, my husband and I will never come back.  I recommend to go elsewhere as this place is not worth the money.

Initially found this place because it was on Diners, Drive Ins and Dives. Read the reviews on yelp, looked at the menu and my taste buds were primed. The food was very tasty with every bite a unique flavor sensation add to that awesome service, cool drink offerings and funky/interesting dcor and this was a hit! We tried the GF Forte Jackass drink which had ginger infused vodka, ginger beer and limes, yum!!! I had the Pelmeni which were Russian style meat dumplings, sprinkled with fresh dill, green onions and served with sour cream. My companion had the Bulgarian Mixed Grill which had 3 types of sausages Kiufte, Kebabche & Loukaniko w/ Bulgarian bean relish, liuteniza & european slaw. Both were fantastic. We finished with a Russian version of a Tiramisu and OMG it was awesome, way better than any Tiramisu I have ever had. My companion had the baklava and it too was different than any baklava we have ever eaten and really delicious. The prices were really reasonable, the entire meal cost us about 35.00. I so wish I lived near enough to go back and eat my way thought the entire menu, over multiple visits of course.
Love this place. The patio in the summer is great! Looks like they recently updated their interior. Can't wait for the Gazpacho to be back on the menu!

You may consider me an expert. I can kill a person for a bowl of good borsht. I know that there are numerous variations of the recipe. The most disgusting version I had at Forte. Please never order it there. The person who prepared it should go straight to culinary hell. 

Borsht is not a bowl of roughly chopped crunchy vegetables lacking any taste or  flavour including salt. 

My second choice was Hungarian Goulash. Although I am not an expert on this I am capable to figure out that this dish should be not what I got: old starchy mashed potatoes covered with the sauce way too spicy for a goulash (think Indian or Thai level) with 5 tiny pieces of meat. 

I guess the waitress may have known that she is serving food not suitable for human consumption and therefore has never asked how was it. 

I am glad I didn't invite my friends to experience Easter European food at this place. I would be really embarrassed.

I was visiting this place from Los Angeles. Once I stepped in the place it went all wrong. It isnt walk in dining, there must be a reservation which I found that out after waitibg at the entrance for over ten minutes. There wasnt a welcoming enviornment there at all. Id say it was because I was the only person of color there but thats a stretch. The food im not sure but the service here from my experience was AWFUL
Good place super comfy, delicious food I love your salads, lentil soup, lambs chops and of course the wine and the super gentil waiters Ilko I think so and the girl no remember the name. Thank you!

It's my first time eating Eastern European food ever.
It's really good I love it.  I tried  Hungarian style.
Best chicken soup I ever had.  If I catch cold, I'll definitely get the chicken soup from here.  
Service is awesome.  It seem like mom and pop place.  I'll try different style next time.

The atmosphere was great.  The theme and the ambiance were nice.   The food?  Well?  While an average American can't tell the difference between a beet soup and a borscht,  a Russian most certainly can.  And while the chebureki and  the stuffed peppers looked like a miniature version of the real thing,  they were a pretty far cry from it.  The vareniki while needed more salt in them but did taste pretty authentic.  If you want to get some idea of Russian food without going to urban.  This is the place for you.

Learned about this place from watching Guy Fieri on Triple D. This place is def. off the beaten path, but well worth the trip if you have a car while in Vegas. The owner is pretty good looking, and the female server at our table was also strangely hot, in a very European way. 

The menu is full of dishes that I can't and won't even try to pronounce, but I dare say that most meat lovers will like their Mixed Grill. The meat was well seasoned and very tasty. Almost felt like I was in Eastern Europe, but without the death metal heads and bad Jason Bourne Villains. 

The bread dish with the egg cracked right in the middle is good too, for all you carbo lovers out there. Prices are way cheap, making this a great destination for foodies in Vegas. HInt- if you want to know what Guy ordered they have little icons in the shape of his head next the dishes.

Best Eastern European restaurant in town for sure! Delicious  authentic food made from scratch, includes Best from Bulgaria, Poland, Ukraine, Serbia, Russia etc. best happy hour, best totally affordable Bulgarian vines, professional and friendly staff. One of my favorites places to eat. Highly recommended! You will not regret.

So I had this restaurant bookmarked on Yelp (can't remember why) and tonight I decided to dine here before heading back to California.  I had the Bulgarian mixed grill and the tapa item, Pan con tomate.  As I was waiting for the food I looked around and noted the restaurant is also a market.  Diners can buy wine and other popular Russian dry goods and packaged foods.  
The menu has so many choices.   I'm eager to try the Russian style pork cutlet with pickle and the filet mignon.  The prices are phenomenally reasonable so I've got to come back here.  
The Bulgarian mixed grill and the tomato bread was delicious.  And service was great!  I sat at the bar and got to converse with the proprietors of this family owned establishment, which is another good reason to come back because We've got to support small businesses.
all i have to say is great service and best chicken noodle soup i have ever had in my life!!!! i can eat it everyday!!!!
Incredible food. Service was okay.  Contemporary restaurant.  Definitely recommend. Great eastern European food

Location: at first I was a little skeptical from the looks on the outside. But when you go in it's a nice low key hole in the wall restaurant. 

Environment: upscale electronic music.  Low ambient music. 

Service and food: servers were knowledgeable and and friendly. 
The food was not what I expected . We tried the Hungarian meat platter: overall good, a dash but saltier, but good with bread. 
Fries with garlic, herb and feta cheese: spectacular side dish that was just wanting for more.
Dessert: biscuit was quite light and good. Paired perfectly with some black coffee. 

Overall a good European tapas place, I wouldn't say so much on the Spanish side of dishes. But I'm happy with what this place has to offer.

Fantastic! Friendly and prompt service. Ordered the Bulgarian Mixed Grill and Gambas al Ajillo (kinda like Shrimp Scampi). Everything was delicious! Very reasonably priced and very cool and clean atmosphere. 

Definitely worth a visit!

Forte is one of the best European places I have ever been to . They have such a big variety of plates , and everything is unique in its way and very delicious . It's a small place , but it's always a good atmosphere . I recommend Forte to everyone who wants to try European food .

Holy cow! This place was great!

I had been wanting to try Forte for some time but put it off because it was a bit out of the way from me. After months of procrastinating I finally committed to having dinner here and I'm sure glad that I did. 

First off the dining area was uniquely comfortable with what I can only describe as an Eastern European atmosphere/vibe. Pretty cool. I didn't catch our waitresses name but she was great! Friendly and helpful to us who are mostly unfamiliar with the cuisine. 

My group ordered a handful of things but these are what stood out:

The Bacon Almond Dates:
Unique flavor pairing but it worked. The bacon was the dominant taste IMO

Shopska Salad:
Tasty fresh and light. Perfect balance for a salad dish. The tomatoes cucumbers and feta were a nice combo

Stuffed Grape Leaves:
Loved them. Perfectly seasoned and the yogurt dill sauce was so good I sopped it up with the table bread (also great).

Thracian Clay Pot:
Delicious. I broke the egg immediately and mixed it around with the sausage/tomatoes/peppers and it was the bomb. Really hot but after I let it cool the flavors packed into that little pot were terrific. 

Bulgarian Mixed Grill:
Not sure exactly what was in it (kind of like a rice meat and veg mixture) but it was another unique yet satisfying flavor combination. I had a hint of sweet that joined nicely with the otherwise savory dish. 

Bulgarian Easter Lamb:
Extremely tender meat with some tasty mashed potatoes and another light salad. Again full of flavor

Some of the soups and salads are vegan and vegetarian options for those interested. Definitely something I will look to try another time. Obviously I would recommend this restaurant to friends or anyone for that matter. It was a great experience

Been here a couple times. very good every time! First saw it on the food network, Guy Fieri does a episode in Vegas and forte was featured.

The inside is decorated all European with posters and pictures of European things. its average size inside and has a full bar also. The staff and service are always very good. 

Ive tried a lot of things and i can never remember the name because its in bulgarian/ russian / or some other language. My favorite though is the meat platter they have.
Its 3 different types of meats sitting on top of diced onions. Comes with a little tomatoe paste and beans. Very flavorful and delicious.

I would definitely come back to hear for lunch/dinner because its very good.

Yep. Im another person who came here after seeing that episode of Triple D featuring our favorite, flame shirt wearing host, Guy Fieri. I had their dish that was a sample of different sausages. The plate was huge and the price was decent. Atmosphere is nice and its dimly lit. Service is nice with nothing major to complain about.

The food seems good based off the sausage sampler i got and they also have great bread. So with bread being served as a default, the place is going to be extremely filling. I never left a place that full that wasnt a buffet. Also their bread is amazing with that odd blend of spices and olive oil they offer.

Service is alright. My only complaint is water not being delivered as fast.

Atmosphere is nice and a bit divey. Dim lights are always nice and theres outdoor seating available if you dont like the inside or the weather is nice.

They serve water in hard liquor bottles which is humorous. The only draw back to this is the limited water youre able to get at a time.

Pros: good food at a decent price for it, complementary bread which is great and filling, nice sense if humor with the water.

Cons: water is limited at a time and it can take some time to get it replaced unless you just ask.

Advice: if youre still hungry after the main dish, just get more bread. Try to ask for 2 sets of water if you drink water that much or have a group of friends.

Our airbnb host suggested this small storefront place fo dinner. The menu is extensive, with dishes from Serbia, Bulgaria, Hungary, every dish prepared with great care. We had almond stuffed dates, petite stuffed peppers, stuffed calamari, mixed grill of sausages, portions were not tiny even though it's a tapas menu. Way above average food and service, full bar, nice atmosphere.We loved it.

Outstanding food at reasonable prices compared to the stripe. It's a little restaurant with live music and a great selection of Bulgarian beer and liquor. The favors of the food is outstanding you won't be disappointed.

Local friends recommend this place so I did no Yelp snooping beforehand, but it turned out to be a huge hit. I will say that food/flavor/atmosphere-wise it deserved 5 stars. However, there were only 2 servers working on a busy Thursday night and although they were trying hard, it definitely hampered the experience a bit.

 
Unfortunately, most of the food was ordered from our friend's memory so I'll have to just describe it rather than name it. Now, about the food:

Starter Salads: 
They ordered two, both of which were topped with generous helpings of a very light and fluffy feta cheese. It sounds like it could be overbearing, but it wasn't and totally worked with each. The first was like a traditional Greek salad with tomatoes, cucumbers, and of course the fresh feta. The second had watermelon and basil with the feta. Both were light, fresh, and very tasty in their own idiom. 

Sleeper pick
We got two helpings of a hot and fluffy pizza crust type bread with a fried egg in the middle. You stir the egg yolk around on top and then tear off chunks of this very tasty seasoned puffy bread slathered in the egg yolk. Words again can't do it justice, but it is sooooo good! Order one just to try and you may have to double down like we did. You are in Vegas after all. 

Main Course Dishes:
We had the Eastern Lamb dish (can't remember the actual Russian title but it was two words with a lot more consonants in a row than usual). It was cooked just a hair too well done for my taste, but in all fairness I didn't order and specify the temperature. The seasoning and flavor was bold and very tasty. 
We also got what was described as "Siberian Burgers" which was cooked perfectly and incredibly flavorful. I highly recommend this. 

The ambiance was very eclectic with EDM versions of the latest dance songs playing in the background, but not overbearingly loud. The lighting is low, but the walls and furniture seemed to be painted and bedazzled gypsy style, which makes you feel like your in the Eastern Bloc and not West of the Vegas Strip. 

I would definitely come back and recommend Forte to friends wanting to eat in a local gem.

It was close by and figured we would give it a try. As we walked in there was a stench so we decided to sit in outside patio. We had a few different dishes. Nothing really that would make me want to come back. Don't get me wrong the food was good and edible but nothing spectacular.

My boyfriend and I have come here twice so far and will most definitely be coming back soon. I love the overall feel and atmosphere of this place. The waitresses definitely add to the authenticity of the restaurant. 

We have gotten the pan con tomate both times because it is so fresh and tasty! We also got a salad with cucumbers, fresh feta, green onions, and roasted peppers and I dusted that dish off quick! We splurged and got the $20 cheese, but, and preserve plate. I did not like the bleu cheese at all but the other 3 were delicious. There was a fig served on the side that was obviously soaked in some sort of alcohol. It was a little overpowering. We ended up taking the leftovers of the cheese plate home.

My boyfriend ordered the clay pot and didn't eat much because he was so stuffed from the cheese and and complementary bread that comes with dinner. We have the leftovers in the fridge right now :P

The first time we came here, we got the vereniki which is like a pirogi. It was so amazing and had a very light flavor. My boyfriend got the goulash and liked it very much! It wasn't what I was expecting but he really enjoyed it. I got the adjarski khachapurri which is a boat-shaped bread with cheese and egg in it. It was soo filling and tasty. I'll definitely get that again!!

As far as drinks, we got 3 different drinks and they were during happy hour so it was cheap! I got an angry ginger lemonade and it was wayyyy too gingery for me so my boyfriend drank it. He ordered the GF forte jackass and said it was too gingery but I thought it wasn't too bad! I wanted to get a drink with no ginger so I asked about the gypsytini and the waitress said there wasn't any ginger in it. I ordered it and I was very impressed! A delightful flavor and not too strong! I can't wait to come back!

Thanks to Guy for putting this place on Triple D! Forte has become our go-to restaurant when we're in Vegas. It's great for date night or an adult gathering, especially if you're a foodie....the kiddies probably wouldn't care for the food. 
You wouldn't expect this amazing place to be in this part of Vegas but it's great. Once you walk in you're immediately taken by the decor, upbeat music & incredible ambience. 
Once greeted by the friendly staff, or owner who is there often, you are brought scrumptious bread. You need to order a pitcher of Sangria! It's pretty delish, not too sweet but just right. 
We always order tapas here & highly recommend items from their specials menu. Last time we were there we had the Lamb Lollipops with Forte Fries...HOLY GOODNESS! Then we had the Artisian Characuterie Plate, also spectacular. It doesn't matter which dish you try, it's a great experience & you will be back for more. 
The decor in here is awesome. Love the bar area & it's also a great place to celebrate a birthday, they were preparig for one when we were there & it looked very festive. 
Can't wait to go back to Vegas for some more Forte!

I came here yesterday while visiting Las Vegas, and I'm so happy I did. I am Bulgarian, and the food brought back so many memories of my childhood living in Bulgaria. The service was excellent and fast, and he food was super fresh and wonderful! I will definitely make it a point to come here every time I'm in Vegas. Highly recommend!

5 Stars on Food. -- come here when its empty for a great meal.
2 Stars on Service -- if its crowded, or a line in front of you, walk away and come back another day.

Being of Eastern European descent, I'll try anyplace that serves borscht, sausage and pirogi, no matter what their language calls it.  We saw Forte on DDD and their Thracian Pot and Mixed Grill platters were a calling to enjoy.

Ate here on a Saturday night.  Their website suggests reservations which, if you want service, I'd recommend.  There were seven of us and we each ordered different plates, all cooked so well.  Everything was perfectly seasoned.  I think Forte put "Tapas" in their name because this place serves your food like its in Europe, which means that your food comes to the table as its prepared -- its not like in the US where every order comes at the same time.  We had some main dishes before appetizers but most all of it came out promptly and we were all allowed to share each others plates.

The Borscht was basic and tasty.  Like at a food court in Moscow.
The dolmas were great -- it reminded me that we haven't made any since our grape leaf sister-in-law ripped out her plant.
The lamb and beef confit were great.
Ask for a carafe of water at the table because service is slow when it gets crowded.
Feta fries were excellent.  Made us think of the last place that we loved feta fries and we still can't remember its name.
The Thracian Pot was excellent
The pirogies, although they're called something else in Cyrillic, were great.
The stuffed meat deep fried turnovers were okay -- could use some more meat in them.  The meat was seasoned and tasty, just could use a little more meat.
The Beef Stroganoff was very very good.  Its something I'll try to recreate at home.  Their sauce was so intense in flavor.  I'll get this again.

I can't think of anything that we didn't enjoy eating.  Unfortunately, they have some problems -- it appears no one want to be a server.  We watched as table after table of people would just get up and walk away -- leave.  They would be seated, and after about 15 minutes of not being waited on, just leave.  All the while, 3 people are behind the bar just hanging out, pouring some drinks but hanging out.  Maybe the waitress's called in sick that day, but I counted about 16 people get up and leave.  That's money walking and never coming back.  I also saw the people next to us sit for a good 30 minutes before being waited on, and then 10 minutes later for some bread, a draft beer and a soda.   Its quite sad because the food is great, but the staff is scaring away the income.
By the way, after everybody in our party of 7 were fed and full, I was still waiting for my mixed grill.  It was about the time where I was deciding whether to just stop by a fast-food on the way home or put out the wait that our server asked if we wanted anything else.  I told her I hadn't had my plate yet.  Another 15 minutes later, it came.  Great plate - 3 kinds of sausage, some cold white bean salad that's not slimy or vinegary, and a red pepper/tomato whip -- I forget the name.  The sausages are all great to try as each has their own flavor and texture.  I was glad I waited.    Next time I'm here, I'm going for the Stroganoff, probably the Borscht again, and perhaps something else.  If I don't have a waitress next time, I'm just ordering at the bar like in Europe.  maybe that's the gig.

Run by some awful women who won't allow corkage.

I made a reservation, then left.

Too bad. Stupid policy.

Ambience, excellent food quality, and cheerful staff.  We arrive at 7:30 on Wed. night to be greeted with a smile and seated immediately with our reservation in a restaurant that was about half full.   First they bring out their homemade bread, to die for, with olive oil and Hungarian spices.  My wife and I are not big bread eaters, but this was sensational.


Like many others, I discovered them on triple D with Fieri.  So many things on the menu look great, but we went with the two highlighted on the show, the mixed grill and the Thracian clay pot.  If you are a pork lover ,this is your place!  All three items on the mixed Grill are prepared differently with unique taste and all were exceptional.  The clay pot with feta cheese, tomato peppers and more sliced pork covered with a baked egg was unbelievably good. The feta cheese took on a flavor I've never had and the tomato was cooked down to be cut with spoon but still have body and flavor.  We cleaned both plates.

At that point I asked for the check as we were trying to make a late show. In passing, my wife said it was my birthday. The hostess would not let us leave without boxing up a dessert to take with us. At no charge!  What an unexpected pleasure and it too was delicious later that night in our room!

You have to have an open mind for this is not your standard fare, but if you're willing to try something out of your comfort zone, it is well worth it!

Love this place off the strip in Vegas.  Been there two times and I can cay that there is love in every bite of their food.  Some favorites were the clay pot, octopus, and the dates but everything was good.  The wine list is reasonable and approachable.  A great alternative for great unfussy food off the strip

I have been going here since it has been open.  I love the atmosphere here and the food is very good and authentic.  My fiance is from Russia and agrees the food is very good.  It is nice to see many Eastern Europeans here at the place.  A big plus is they put on UFC fights for free!!!!  Nina the owner is very nice and awesome.  I would highly recommend this place to anyone who desires a small, great Eastern European place.

Had a fantastic meal here. I loved that the food was prepared by the family who own the restaurant. The friendly waitress was passionate about the menu and was a perfect guide through what to try. We had the charcuterie board and some tapas dishes and it was all delicious and unique. The cocktails were great too. Try the Hungarian Sour - the frozen grapes were a fun touch. Absolutely will be coming back again.

5 of us met again to try a new restaurant and try different food.  I have had Forte bookmarked for about 2 years but I never seemed to think of this place.  

We were seated at two high top tables right as you come in the door.  While we were looking at the menu and talking about other things, we were approached for our order.  We asked her to wait awhile as we kept studying what we wanted.

We were soon brought some bread.  They were large round puffs larger and flatter than a doughnut.  There was olive oil on the table and we pulled pieces off the bread to dip in the oil.  It was good.

Our things started coming out.  The first plate was a shared Spanish "nacho" platter.  It consisted of some chips with thin chorizo slices and topped with a tasty truffle salsa.

We were brought two orders of meat pies that were also good.  Next came a dish stuffed baby squid served over Spanish herb rice.  

We also ordered each of their specialty breads--a feta cheese stuffed filo dough round and Adjarski Khachapurri, described as traditional Georgian boat shaped bread filled with two types of Georgian styled pickled cheeses and a cracked egg mixed on top (after our photos).  Both were good breads.  It was difficult cutting the Georgian bread with the egg but we managed to mangle it enough that everyone got a chance to try some.  The filo round was easy.  All we had to do was pull a piece of the roll off and dip it in the sour cream if we wanted.  The bread was brought straight from the oven because it was extremely hot.

We had two orders of almond stuffed bacon wrapped dates with a sherry reduction.  The dates were OK but I thought they were cooked a bit too much.

Next came some Easter or spring lamb with some mashed potatoes and some salad.  I didn't think the lamb had much of the lamb flavor I was expecting and it was in a dark sauce.  I guess I'm too used to having lamb rare and not done in a stew manner.  It was extremely tender.

We closed out this part of lunch with the Thracian clay pot described on the menu as a "traditional Bulgarian specialty of tomatoes, peppers, onion, feta, Bulgarian style charcuterie, and egg baked in a Bulgarian clay pot.  For me, this was the stand out of our lunch.  it had lots of flavor.  I used some of the spice on the table to give it some extra flavor.  On the table was a spice boat with a small wooden spoon.  The woman told us that it was a mixture of 40 spices with cumin, garlic, salt, and.....  We didn't ask her to continue.

Then dessert was ordered.  We got some baklava and their biscuit cake.  The biscuit cake was the star!  The menu describes it as "decadent cake layered with honey biscuits, mascarpone, rich chocolate, Lavazza espresso, and a kick of spiced rum topped with walnuts and more chocolate.  Need I write any more?  The baklava was not like I'm used to in how it's made but it was OK.

I thought the food was pretty good.  I wanted to give the place more stars but the part that held me back was the service.  We had asked at the start not to bring all the dishes out but they just kept coming--not all at once--but close enough together that there wasn't a chance to rest a bit between tastings.  The number of plates and fitting them on our two tables became a bit of an issue.  Instead of giving us clean plates periodically, we had the same ones until the main courses were completed.  We got clean plates for dessert.  We also had to ask twice to get more water.  For such a small place with two servers at least, things should have been done better.  

I might go back to try one of the other main dishes.  And of course, getting some more biscuit cake should always be foremost in my mind.

As always, good company made lunch a much better time!

I enjoyed quite the delicious dinner at this quaint little place. Offering a variety of cuisine from the European continent, but I settled for the Beef Stroganoff Ragu, not served over noodles, but pelmeni stuffed with mushrooms for $9.

Before the stroganoff arrived, the meal started with some moist house Russian bread with a side of extra virgin olive oil and some red spices, mostly made of paprika. The Russina wheat bread was great and eaten with the dressed up olive oil was bliss. 

The Stroganoff was quite the treat. First of all, the ragu was very well made. It was thick and rich with a great flavor: a deep rich flavor that took time to develop, and some skill to make. Somebody had a great recipe hidden back there.  The pelmeni's mushrooms inside were tender, very well seasoned, and had a great natural flavor. Also, the pelmeni's itself, the shell, had a great chewiness in a very good way. No doubt they were cooked well. I'm telling you, I could of eaten a mountain of these. 

I also tried tasters from a Bulgarian Mixed Grill which was quite good. Nataliya, the server was absolutely amazing. She not only was very well verse in Forte's cuisine and its individual preparations, but she reserved extreme patience. She was very prompt and always had a great smile on her face.

If you are looking for something different and great, check this place out.

I took my wife and mom here for mothers day as I saw this in a book of top 100 restaurants and mom love beef stroganov which they serve.  

I tried to order a wine, they did not have it.  I tried to order another wine, they did not have that one.  Third time was the charm.

I like the lamb confetti ap, very good.  My goulash was not really hot when served.  I had a soup with pickled meat that was interesting and tasty.

The honey cake for desert was tasty.  

I would go back if in the area, but this will not be a regular place I visit.

My service experience was good.

My wife and I popped into this place one day randomly after stocking up at Lee's. We now frequent it at least 3-4 times a month. Everything we have had has been great! The service is always spot on. The menu is far more interesting than you will find at most places in town. The place is small so reservations are recommended for a Friday or Saturday but they are very accomodating. Go before  word gets out, amazing food at reasonable prices never lasts long!

The food was really good, but the service was pretty terrible.  We'll go back again for a second try.  The Bulgarian mixed grill was awesome.  The beef and lamb confit was spectacular.  I also enjoyed the dates wrapped in bacon.  the prices are very reasonable.  Atmosphere a little loud and it's more of a bar than a restaurant.  The food was so great that I am willing to overlook any of the other issues.  The biscuit cake was sort of like terramisu and tasted really good.
Oh goodness gracious. Bite size pieces of heaven in all forms. Watermelon salad? Filled dates? Truffle Potatoes? How did this even come to be? Worth every dollar. But. Plan on spending a lot of them.

What a fun place!  We had chorizo in wine, the Serrano ham and manchego, a lamb ragu special, the Thracian clay pot and plenty of their good bread. All of it was excellent, made even more enjoyable by our waitress Natalia!  We'd go back in a minute. Thank you!!

I have been here a few times while visiting Vegas.  I first learned about this place from the Guy's TV show.  This place is the bomb.  As a group we tried about 12 different menu items.  All were good.   

Service was also solid.

Give this place a try.

2018 update - here again!  Still delish!  Keep up the good work!

FUN! This place is a funky bar with another world feel to it, I feel like I had been transported to Eastern Europe for the night, FUN!! Both the wine and food menu are diverse and interesting with lots of options for meat lovers and vegetarians alike.

Note, try the bread with the feta baked into it its AMAZING!!!!!!!!

I went here with a friend and let him order what he has tried and or what I may like. I had stuffed peppers, stroganoff,  mushrooms and a few other dishes and each one was amazing. Very fresh and cooked well food. Service was very home like feeling and was very enjoyable. I can't wait to go back.

I've only been here once but my experience was great. The waitresses where foreign which gave the place a more authentic feel. The food is so good and the service great. Check out their drink menu and try the Gipsy Milk. It's kind of like a Moscow mule but so much better.

Absolutely amazing food! I am always the one to try something different and this was a great pick. 

Servers were wonderful, fast and attentive.

Food was amazing! We ordered Olive sampler, Borsht, Hungarian Goulash, Stuffed Peppers and the Thracian Clay Pot. EVERYTHING was superbly prepared. I will definitely be going back.
The mixed sausage platter was salty and the bacon wrapped dates were burnt. Food was better a few other times we've been here so this was disappointing.

Forte has been on my radar for years.  Ever since I saw it on "Diners, Drive-ins, and Dives."  I don't know why it took me so long to get here but I finally did the other night.  And now I am kicking myself for not making it in sooner because it is so good.  From the food to the friendly hospitality asking me how the food was, how my beer was, if I needed more ice for my water.  This was well worth the visit, long as it may have taken me to get around to.

I had a wonderful meal sitting alone in the back corner of the dining room observing all the art work and people spread throughout the establishment.  It wasn't overly busy on a Tuesday evening around 5:30 but there were a few groups of people.  One small group outside, a small group inside, a larger group a little closer to where I sat, and a couple.  I could not tell if they all could hear the music playing or if they were even paying attention to it but I can tell you that I was rocking out.  I sat almost directly below the speaker.  I closed my eyes and was suddenly transported to an Eastern European night club (think "Eurotrip").  I half expected to hear "Scotty Doesn't Know" at any moment.  I'm not always into dance hall type music but in this case, it was fitting.

My meal started with the complimentary bread basket with a saucer of olive oil sprinkled with the spice blend sitting on each table.  I know there was a little bit of salt in the blend.  Beyond that, I am at a loss.  It was good though and that is all that matters.  

Next up on my tour of the menu was a Bulgarian beer, Zakorga, which came with a complimentary meat plate.  On this plate was four pieces of cured meat similar to salami in appearance, two gerkins and an olive complete with pit.  The meat was not as salty or spicy as salami.  Rather it was the sweet nuttyness of a natural dry cured meat almost like a prosciutto.  What a perfect accompaniment to a beer.    

To start my actual meal, I ordered stuffed grape leaves and beef stroganoff ragu.

The grape leaves are meat stuffed and served hot with a rich yogurt sauce topped with fresh dill and parsley.  There was a wedge of lemon on the side.  A quick spritz of juice over the leaves really rounded out the plate.  The vibrant acidity cut through the richness of the yogurt nicely.  

The stroganoff that came up next was also very rich.  It was a ground beef strognaoff in a full bodied sour cream sauce served over wild mushroom pelmeni (dumplings).  It was very good on its own but, in hindsight, the spice blend next to me would have been a fitting addition. 

What meal is complete without dessert? I was considering the baklava but after hearing the Bulgarian Biscuit Cake described to me, I knew that was my dessert.  I was told it is made with a type of cake that cannot be found anywhere else in the valley.  And that it was layered with a cream filling like tiramisu, one of my favorite desserts.  How could I even think about passing this up?  I was surprised by the size of this cake.  It was bigger than I expected but not as rich I as thought it may be.  The cake used seemed more like a bread which helped to cut down the sweetness.  With the almost but not quite bitter dark chocolate sauce on top, it was balanced out to perfection and was the best possible way to end my meal.  I left with a soft smile on my face that only ended later when I was at home and the euphoria wore off.

How could we have missed such a wonderful place for so long? Angry Ginger Lemonade is so refreshing and delicious. Everything we had was so wonderful.  Borscht just like grandma used to make. Watermelon Salad, Gazpacho, Mediterranean Salad, Watermelon Feta Salad, Gamba al Ajilio and Bulgarian Mixed Grill. The waitress was delightfully entertaining. The worst part of our visit was trying to decide what we liked best. Will be returning often.

Ok, food here is ok, they have some interesting dishes thats why 2 stars not 1, but beware of the VODKA SCAM. In the menu it's not mentioned how much vodka do you get for the price of $14 ( which is like in bulgaria considered a small vodka or 50 ml) this isn't written on there so when you order a glass of vodka they ask you big or small and the BIG ONE it's not on the menu 100 ml its $28!!!!!!!!! I have been to fancy restaurants, 17 course mega luxury ones and NEVER ever seen just a vodka ( without the mixer or made like a cocktail) to be $28. So there you go at the end you had 3 drinks and your bill is $84 thats without the juice or the red bull, WHhhhaaaaTTT?????? Our eyes popped out. Where are we? Please consider if going to this place, don't order alcohol - WAY OVERPRICED!! portions are super small too, like you are doing fine dining but without the fine dining atmosphere lol. It'a regular looking restaurant with price of a 7 star place in Dubai. Beware!

My food friend, Max, brought me here for a different experience. It certainly was different from anything I've ever experienced in Vegas. Forte offers a wide variety of Eastern European tapas with delicacies from Russia, Bulgaria, Hungary, Turkey, etc. The drinks were awesome - my favorite was the Angry Ginger Lemonade.

Have had the pleasure of enjoying Fortes food many times in the past two years but just writing about it now. Lastnight, came in with wife and baby. Great atmosphere and food came up very fast. Happy to report that all the changes since the last visit have only improved forte to a whole new level. I feel as if it's a place to go if you are in the industry after work, or even as a causal guest. There is something on the menu for everyone and, more importantly, something new for everyone to try. Giving 5 well deserved stars becuase the owner obviously cares about her guests, as she is always there to give a personal touch to the venue. The only thing that I would say that I commented on was the amount of staff working. Just seemed like too many, but maybe they had a party coming in or something. Happy Cooking/Eating!

Really enjoy this place, but slightly pricey when you consider the size of the portions and the casual environment. Not a fan of the table we were seated at. It was really uncomfortable. I think if we were more comfortable we would've sat there longer and maybe ordered more food, but it's okay. Food is super interesting. Fun to try. I would go again.
Great authentic Russian Food. The owner is amazing, who really cares about her customers! Really good place to eat and hang out that is low key. Ate there recently, very yummy food and great service!

We found this place by accident me and my boyfriend were hungry and decided to search for TAPAS on the Yelp app. Behold Forte came with with good reviews and it was so close to our houses. We went on last week Friday and enjoyed it so much we came back Saturday. Last night we came back to have dinner before our Diana Ross concert. Our goal is to try everything on the menu. They also have good beers that he enjoys and I myself have taken a liking to their mojito.
ALL IN ALL amazing food and fantastic staff and environment.

Nice little unassuming place as a perfect starter for a trip to Europe.  Came here with two others.

Ambiance - 4 Stars.  From the outside patio, it looks like any other small restaurant hole in the wall in a strip mall.  It does have outside seating, but inside is better.  Go inside, and the decor/feel is more like an old Seattle Coffee House or a quaint European eatery.  It was quirky, funky, comfortable, relaxed, charming, and generally upbeat.  Great for loud conversations with good friends.

Service - 5 Stars.  From the host when we walked in to the server, the staff were stellar.   We were greeted and seated promptly, with a welcoming smile.  The server was happy to spend time discussing the different dishes, and free and honest in her critiques when we asked her opinion of various dishes.  She kept tabs on us and our progress throughout the meal, timing herself perfectly so as to never come over when our mouths were full of food, but also making sure we were lacking nothing, and even timing perfectly to ask if we were enjoying our dishes.  At the end of the meal, and after dessert, she was happy to chat with us and give me suggestions of food and alcohol to have on an upcoming trip.  Truly professional, super friendly staff here.

Food - 4.5 Stars.  Our starter was the Epicurious Cheese Plate ~ excellent choice with a varied selection of four cheeses paired with nuts and preserves - my oddly favorite mix was the bell pepper type jelly paired with the Qeso de Cabra (I never expected to like bell pepper flavored jelly, but it worked so very well with the cheese).  For main courses we had Hungarian Goulash, Bulgarian Easter Lamb, and Serbian Mixed Grill (yes, we oddly hit up three different countries there).  The Goulash and Lamb were both reviewed as great (though the goulash had one piece of dried spice that had not fully blended in - thus the -.5 star) by those eating the dish, and for me, the Serbian Mixed Grill was a perfect match for my craving.  The spices for the mixed grill meats were unusual for me, but a nice pairing.  The server warned it might be spicy, but i found it to be very mild with a great overall flavor.  I'm not sure what the name of the sausage was, but it was perhaps the most uniquely flavored (in a positive way) sausage I've had.  For dessert, which we almost passed up because we were stuffed by this time (don't DON'T pass up dessert here), we tried the Bulgarian Biscuit Cake, which is basically a lighter, smoother, more yummy version of tiramisu ~ as in, tiramisu 2.0.  Don't question it, just order it.  What's a few pounds between friends?

Drink - 5 Stars.  They have Ginger Beer.  I got addicted to that stuff in Australia, and to find it here anywhere was amazing.  That aside, my friend had a red wine that was very nice and full bodied with hints of berry and no overpowering wood flavor (sorry I forget the name of the wine).  I had a Troyanska Rakija, which is apparently a plum brandy.  I ordered it because of the name, without knowing what it was, and with instructions to the server to not tell me, which she chuckled at, and warned me not to drink it in one shot when she brought it to the table.  The Troyanska Rakija was excellent, from the nice, vaguely fruity scent, to the warm glow it imparted.

Recommendations - Come here with friends and expect to have light-hearted fun.  Have the Bulgarian Biscuit Cake, and then whatever else tickles your fancy at the time.  Try the Troyanska Rakija.  And if you've only ever had Ginger Ale, do yourself a favor and order a Ginger Beer.

Avoid - Nope, I've got nothing.  Oh, yes, if you're seated inside, avoid the step, especially if you choose to drink.

I really wanted to like Forte more than I did. I went in optimistic and came out kind of disappointed. 

Part of it was just bad luck. My wife ordered a diet coke and got light brown water because the fountain was down and the server hadn't noticed. She instead ordered a mango juice only to find that they were out. So she had a peach juice instead, which was good but tasted a little bit too much like canned peaches for my tastes. I ordered a mojito. It was plenty strong, but the bartender didn't use enough sugar and the mint was pretty obviously on its way out. I also don't think it got much of a muddle, if any.

The first thing they bring out foodwise is their house-made bread, which was nice and flavorful, especially dipped in the olive oil which is fruity and fragrant. There is a little wooden boat with herbs for the oil, only we weren't provided a spoon so it was difficult to use it. Not a big deal. We managed.

We ordered the pelmeni, vareniki, serrano and manchego, and garlic herb fries. The fries were tasty and they brought plenty of them, so if you're looking for filler it's a good bet. The garlic could have been a little stronger, but I'm kind of a garlic fiend so take that with a grain of salt. The pelmeni were juicy and delicious and the dumpling wrappers had bite and weren't waterlogged. The manchego and serrano was good, but I would have appreciated the ham being cut into pieces so we didn't have to hack the thing up every time we wanted some. It came with some alcaparrones (caperberries) that added some vinegar contrast to what is otherwise a fatty/salty dish.

The vareniki themselves were tasty, but the fried onions that came on top weren't fried - they were burnt. Instead of deliciously caramelized onions, I got black chunks of carbon with some residual onion flavor. Since the vareniki have a delicate flavor on their own, it overpowered the dumplings and killed the dish.

One other thing: the seating is mostly low cafe tables, so you end up kind of hunching over to get at your food. I think we'd have enjoyed it more sitting at one of the tall bar tables or even at the bar itself.

We're going to give the place another shot, because I don't think anyone should rule out a restaurant based on one experience, but this one wasn't entirely positive.

Eastern European food with a flair! We were looking for a good location for a nice meal, off the strip and away from the crowds and we're glad we found this place! The service was friendly, the atmosphere was great, and the food was good. We had the Bulgarian mixed grill, fries with beef stroganoff, and Hungarian ghoulish. All were good and I would recommend this place for larger groups or a romantic night out!

This review is solely based on their food. We got a pitcher of sangria the pan con jamon with manchengo cheese, olives, chorizo, and fries. I could order 20 pans it was so light and crispy and ooey gooey cheesy the touch of tomato under the jamon really adds a pop of flavor. The olives were just right and a great mix of green and black- be careful because they're topped with whole green peppers that I thought would be like the olives but they're freaking spicy ass peppers! The fries we got both the herb and garlic and the feta. Both were really good. They play good music too which is nice.

Everything was amazing ! I am so happy , the food was delicious and this place definitely made me feel like I was at home- in Bulgaria! It is an unique place, where you can experience something different and new form the Eastern European(mostly Bulgarian) and Russian cosine! My American friends and husband loved it , not sure if they will have Rakia (Bulgarian strong alcohol drink) ever again but after all for that you need years of proper training first lol

This place was fantastic. We went for happy hour, $5 drinks and 5$ apps. The stroganoff fries were bomb. The drinks were quite good, and the bartender was super friendly. It's a unique concept, the European tapas, but I have to say I really liked it and will be back. $5 drinks until 6 $5 apps unti 7.

I really wanted to like Forte. A reasonably priced European tapas restaurant in Vegas, sounds amazing ! Unfortunately, the restaurant did not top more than 3 stars. 

First the service was sooooo slow. This is not a large restaurant, but it took our server over 20 minutes to bring a menu. We had to ask for drinks several times, and we had to ask for a second set of flatware 3 times. 

I started with a ginger lemonade cocktail served in a bronze mug. Delicious! This was the winner. Well worth my $8.

We ordered borscht, a cold beet and cabbage soup, a particular favorite from Eastern Europe and Russia; truffle mashed potatoes; and stroganoff. Each was good but not great. We followed up with the beef and lamb confit, and the star course of the night, lamb lollipop chops! 

I did not care for the size of the portions. Forte holds itself out as a tapas restaurant, but each of these dishes were large enough for a full course. Smaller dishes and smaller prices would be preferable, otherwise this is just an Eastern European/ Russian fusion restaurant and not a tapas place.

The atmosphere is nice and Forte makes for an interesting date spot. I look forward to trying Forte again and hopefully improving their 3 star rating.

Outstanding food. I really like the octopus. Tapas are a great way to try many dishes. This place is fun with a small group. The seating is a little funky but not a problem. The service is very helpful. We enjoy eating here.

Not bad.  Quite interesting as they aren't the usual tapas.  Some very unique european influences.  I say it is good but with the other amazing tapas restos in the valley (maybe just cause i've had sangria at all the others and stayed dry here).  Worth checking out and the vibe is fun, but really could get better flavors for my personal pallette at elements, firefly, or barcelona.  Still you might find a unique favorite on their menu if u are willing to try!

This out of the way, hole in the wall from the outside establishment, is our new favorite spot in Vegas!! We had gotten the recommendation from my new hairdresser, self-professed Foodie, Jenna Moreno. It did not disappoint!! We started off with Martini's - I had a Russian Vodka and Hubby had a Honey Pepper Vodka that was Spicy and Delicious!! We took the recommendation from our server and got the Serbian Mixed Grill (which was a sumptuous festival of sausages!!) and the Bulgarian Easter Lamb that Hubby said was the best Lamb he had ever had!! And for dessert, the "Famous Bulgarian Biscuit Cake" that was divine!! If you're in the mood for something different and delicious, this is the place!!

Great service 

Knowledgable server 

Unreal food cooked perfectly ( I had the squid and lamb chop plates) and a perfectly recommended beer

I'll definitely come back w my love-a must have stop

My Hungarian husband found Forte through Yelp because he had a craving for lngos.  We made the half hour trek to this restaurant earlier today to give it a try.  We arrived shortly after they opened at noon and were immediately seated.  The place is cozy and dim, which would have been more relaxing if the music had been softer and chill - they were piping in some loud house/techno/whatever it was.  We ordered the lngos, of course, along with the Spanish breakfast and palachinka.  Everything was delicious and filling, however it took a really long time to get our food.  We were one of only three other tables there at the time but all of us had to wait over 30 minutes to even get some bread.  The server was very prompt and efficient so it seemed as though it was the fault of the kitchen, as though it simply wasn't prepared for opening hours.  Not a very good first impression, however we'll give Forte another try later since sometimes unfortunate things happen and we did appreciate the tastiness of the food.

Great place with very diverse selection of Eastern European dishes. My favorite is the chicken soup and the mixed grill. The pizza/flatbread is insanely good as well. There are a number of items for sale as a deli style specialty store that adds character to the restaurant. Staff is very welcoming and attentive. If it was not a 45min drive for me to get there I would probably be there every other day.

The best little hole in the wall in Vegas!

Came here with a group of girlfriends from work, one being from Russia. We had made a reservation ahead of time, for which I was glad. At 7 pm, the place was pretty packed, but began clearing out a bit around 8 pm. 

Here's what was on our table:

Adjarski Khachapurri - giant boat bread with soft cheese and a cracked egg. This was amazing. The flavor wasn't overdone and it was fresh out of the oven!

Beef Strogannoff Ragu - we all know what this is and it was awesome

Vereniki and Pelmeni - two different types of dumplings with sour cream. They were not overly greasy and paired with the sour cream...amazing!.

We ordered some of their signature house drinks and a bottle of wine. 

I have to give the food 5 stars. It was so nice to go to a place where the tapas wasn't pre-made and sitting under heat lamps getting greasy and dried out (*cough* Firefly *cough*). The food was not overly seasoned to cover up the lack of quality...like a lot of places do. The vegetables and fresh seasonings (scallions, parsley, etc.) served with each dish really complimented the home cooking and quality ingredients. 

The service was slow, but due to everything being fresh out of the oven, it was more than acceptable. Plus, in Euro culture, you take your time to eat and talk. Why is everyone in such a hurry?! We stayed here for over 4 hours listening to the live music and chatting away. It was a really nice atmosphere, and we all left happy.

The food here is amazing. Everything tasted great and the waiter had wonderful recommendations. The mango juice is a must try for those not ordering alcoholic beverages. I will definitely be going here again in the near future.

I am unfamiliar with European cuisine so I was definitely in for a treat when I visited Forte! 

I first experienced this wonderful restaurant with one of MGM's executive chefs. He is a die hard foodie so I trusted his recommendation and was excited to explore a new type of food. We went with another friend and shared a variety of dishes and tapas:
 
- Stuffed Baby Squid
My favorite dish. Glazed/marinated in its own ink and served on a bed of herb rice. The squid came out room temperature but the rice was nice and warm! I would not recommend for picky eaters - only if you want to try something unique and are a fan of octopus/squid. I recall the texture being soft and not very chewy like squid can tend to be 

- Braised lamb
Tender lamb was paired with a light salad and mashed potatoes. The lamb was very flavorful/incredibly soft!

- Stroganoff Fries 
Delicious fries topped with beef stroganoff. So. Addicting. It was a great plate to share and the stroganoff ragu was excellently seasoned!

- Bread Boat
Freshly baked bread filled with tasty cheese, topped with a delicious egg that's cooked right into the top/middle of the bread. We heard this was a staple/must try and were not disappointed! We broke the egg into the bread and very much enjoyed this as an appetizer 

- Meat Grill Platter
A smorgasbord of meats served with a side of fries and white rice. The sausages were extremely salty (for someone who loves sodium) but it was neat to be able to taste various traditional European meats

I ordered the Ghost Rider IPA and our server brought out the glass bottle of beer with a sweet clay mug designed with Aztec patterns. I may or may not have been overly excited about how cool this mug looked.   

I remember the service being fantastic which only added to our awesome experience trying new dishes. I have not been back since my original visit but would definitely go back - most likely with someone familiar with the menu!
just visited for the 4th time... bad service with major attitude and a bonus of food poisoning for both my daughter and myself. Way up and way down.

I was visiting a friend and she took me here. O my god, I still dream of their stuffed peppers and beef/lamb confit. This place is a hole in the wall that only locals really know, but please, if you are looking for excellent euro tapas you will find it at forte.

what a cool place. food is amazing, really delicious!! house infused vodkas.. what can i say? the best vodka I've ever tried, and I'm Russian, I do know whats good :)) Anyways, i live in LA, but everytime I'm in Vegas, this is the place where I meet with all my friends! Love this Bar/Restaurant!!

This place is really cute. Love love love the decor. Very female oriented. Our waitress was adorbs and super sweet. I wasn't eating much but the table bread was delicious they have some yummy spice combo you add to the olive oil that is really good flavor I've never had before. We had the clay pot with egg. Egg was over cooked and that kind of ruined it, but I've never had Bulgarian food so maybe it's supposed to be that way? Grape leaves were good delicious dill sauce. We can't remember the other dish we had so it wasn't very memorable. Very laid back vibe is what we liked most. The beer selection was interesting and you get a hobbit mug for them. Moscow mule was really good. They infuse their own vodka with ginger. Family friendly. Bought a bottle of wine to go it was disgusting.... From Spain. So don't get that.

Upon entering Forte on my initial visit, my first thought was that it was very European. This wasn't just because it was dead at lunch, as most restaurants in Europe are, but also because of the eccentric decor, dark lounge-like feel, off-the-beaten-path location, and genuine hospitality. That, and the fully stocked bar featuring very cheap glasses of delicious European wines (this I would find out later).

I've over-ordered Forte at twice now, and though I can't say everything on the small plates menu is a winner, I can say I will keep coming back due to the aforementioned charming qualities and a few unique, inexpensive food highlights.

The menu is broken down by European country (mostly Eastern) and their corresponding regional specialties. Under Russia, you won't find any caviar or borscht, but you will find adjarkski kachapurri, which goes down the hatch more easily than it rolls off the tongue ($6.99). This consists of a freshly baked bread loaf akin to a short, fat French baquette, that is hollowed in the center and stuffed with cheese, butter, and a raw egg. If I lost you at 'raw egg' then let me elaborate. The egg is mixed in table-side and is cooked by the heat of the bread, turning the dish into a protein-filled vegetarian friendly dish that will change your mind about Russian food. The flavor of the crusty bread combined with the egg and cheese reminded me of a quiche, yet this was unlike anything I've ever had. Extra (yet unnecessary) points for that!

The section from Spain features a variety of chorizo sausages, amongst other items. We had the chistora and bilbao (each $2.50) which were fantastically charred and of fantastic value. These rivaled the Polish links at Costco as far as sausage bargains go, and were much better in my opinion.

One note selections included the chicken skewers ($3.25 each), sauteed shrimp ($6.50), and the Bulgarian shopski served in an adorable clay pot ($6.99). Though there are a few minor flops, the thing I love most about this place is that you can try a lot of different foods you've probably never heard of, and, if you don't like them, you haven't spent enough to regret having given them a whirl.

Coming back to the wine, I ordered a glass of Spanish Cosechero Blanco, which I was told cannot be found anywhere else in Vegas. Guess how much? $4.50!! The owner of the restaurant, who was our waitress on my second visit, and a gem in and of herself, offered to sell me a bottle at wholesale cost when I mentioned I liked it. So, I got a bottle for later that cost me just $8.20. That pretty much sealed the deal for me!

This is a place you have to be experimental and open-minded to go to, but if you appreciate other cultures and want to join me on my mission to support the mom and pops in Vegas, then you'll have no trouble mustering the strength to go to Forte.

After reading an article about Forte in the newspaper, I checked the Yelp reviews.  Buoyed by those, mostly favorable, from my Yelp peeps, we had a go at it last night.  All I can say is "Cada uno a su gusto," or for you gringos, to each his own.  My husband rated this a grudging two stars.  But I'm the reviewer, and I take his ratings solely under advisement.  My extra star is for the beautiful crockery and matching salt and pepper shakers, all available for purchase near the front.  No need to tell your mom the restaurant "gifted" you.

We arrived a little before 9 p.m., saw the sign "Wait to be seated," so we waited.  And waited some more, until finally a server appeared an offered our choice of tables in the nearly-empty dining room.  

The cocktail menu was lengthy, but perplexingly, only one single item had a price.  I didn't order it, but what made that one special?  Instead, I had a glass of sangria, described as fruity, and with the addition of Armagnac.  I like it when sangria is kicked up with more than just wine.  In this case, the fruit consisted of a slice of lemon.  There was no sweetness whatsoever, and the brandy was undetectable.  In short, it was a mere glass of red wine.  And I don't drink red wine, unless it's sangria, which this wasn't.

The confusion continued.  I had seen the Yelp photos.  The heralded Thracian Clay Pot was not listed under the tapas menu, so I assumed that it would be a dish that we could share.
